stream_context.summary: Kaze live-models and scripts Course 11, “Oily Boily Bay,” focusing on wind-turbine mechanics, crane hooks, and red-coin layout while debugging gimbal-lock rotation issues. He shows engine performance tests, discusses design philosophy, and fields art/texture help from Biobak.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 modelling is almost finished; programming phase will start next. The ROM sits at 42.8 MB, safely under the 64 MB limit.
development_findings.quote: We're in course 11 and we are 42.8 megabytes in size, so…

development_findings.summary: Introduced vertical and horizontal wind-turbine objects that periodically blow Mario; timing is controlled by beeper variables and will be used for red-coin platforming.
development_findings.quote: Let's have this be off for like two seconds and then on for like eight seconds, see how that works out.

development_findings.summary: Solved gimbal-lock problem that made turbines spin on the wrong axis by pre-rotating the model 90° inside Blender and using a separate model file.
development_findings.quote: MFs will never believe you how hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.

development_findings.summary: Planned level layout: circular path around a Bowser statue, multiple underground entrances, an unfinished power generator area, and construction beams behind the statue.
development_findings.quote: What if we just made this go all the way around Bowser … and then you can go underground here and there will be an underground section where you can get the 8-bit pipe.

development_findings.summary: Crane platforms now accept an attachable hook actor so Mario can grab on directly; this will house a red coin and star spawn.
development_findings.quote: That already works. We just move this into the proper location and then we're good to go on the hook.

development_findings.summary: Oil-covered water uses a rainbow shader look; Kaze contemplates adding heat-wave effects but worries about real-hardware frame loss.
development_findings.quote: That's like an N64-only effect and I would add like two frames of input lag—that's why I don't like it.

development_findings.summary: Engine optimisations (cache-box, rewrite) let Course 1 render with ‘infinite’ draw distance at ~20–30 FPS on real N64 hardware, up from 9 FPS in the old branch.
development_findings.quote: This is an N64 game … you can see the birds from here. It runs just fine.

context_findings.summary: Bike was stolen earlier that day; Kaze starts stream in a bad mood but jokes with chat.
context_findings.quote: I'm in a bad mood because my bike was stolen.

context_findings.summary: Diagnosed with tennis elbow; refused cortisol injections and painkillers, preferring self-treatment.
context_findings.quote: He said he might have to inject steroids … I said nah, I'll just treat myself.

context_findings.summary: Frustration that serious technical videos underperform compared to April Fools grass video; believes YouTube meta favors long ‘background-noise’ content.
context_findings.quote: This stupid meme video, 160k … No one gives a shit about anything.

context_findings.summary: Planning a vacation next week, expects more development streams during that time.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I'm gonna have a vacation in a week, too. So with that vacation I can probably stream a lot.

context_findings.summary: Migrating streams from Twitch to YouTube due to Twitch’s decline; happy to hit a personal record of 50 concurrent viewers.
context_findings.quote: I am trying to transition from Twitch because Twitch is going down the gutter.

biobak.summary: Attempted to locate or recreate a turbine texture PSD; willing to remake it quickly if missing.
biobak.quote: I can just remake it because that literally took 30 seconds to make.

biobak.summary: Provided critical feedback on camera behaviour, prompting Kaze to adjust it.
biobak.quote: Lilaa was complaining about it and I kind of saw her point.

biobak.summary: Designed a new stream-banner graphic, which Kaze adopted during the stream.
biobak.quote: Alright, we have a new stream banner.

key_stories.title: The Turbine Gimbal-Lock Battle
key_stories.summary: While adding wind turbines, Kaze discovers that all three Euler rotations behave identically, preventing the blades from facing horizontally. After extensive trial, he realises the engine’s gimbal-lock limitation and fixes it by pre-rotating the model in Blender and loading a separate asset.
key_stories.challenge: Turbine rotation axes were wrong regardless of pitch, roll, or yaw values.
key_stories.process: Debugged code, experimented with beeper timers, inspected windmill reference, eventually rotated the mesh 90° in Blender and re-exported.
key_stories.outcome: Horizontal turbines now spin correctly and power new platforming sections.
key_stories.key_quote: MFs will never believe you how hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.

key_stories.title: Camera Re-tune from Community Feedback
key_stories.summary: Lilaa complained about the previous camera behaviour, leading Kaze to tweak its logic before the stream. He checks with chat to confirm the improvement.
key_stories.challenge: Previous camera felt awkward to testers.
key_stories.process: Reviewed Lilaa’s critique, altered camera parameters, solicited real-time feedback.
key_stories.outcome: New camera version accepted by chat; shows the team’s iterative, feedback-driven workflow.
key_stories.key_quote: The camera is slightly different; Lilaa was complaining about it and I kind of saw her point.

key_stories.title: YouTube Algorithm Reality Check
key_stories.summary: Kaze observes that his April Fools grass video outperformed in-depth technical uploads, reshaping his content strategy.
key_stories.challenge: High-effort technical videos receive fewer views than comedic skits.
key_stories.process: Compared view counts live, theorised that YouTube now rewards background-noise length over substance.
key_stories.outcome: Plans to release a humorous April 1st video every year and brainstorm more click-friendly topics.
key_stories.key_quote: This stupid meme video, 160k … My preview that I spent hundreds of hours on, 120k.

key_stories.title: Doctor’s Visit and Self-Treatment
key_stories.summary: A doctor diagnosed Kaze with tennis elbow and proposed cortisol injections and painkillers, but Kaze refused, deciding to manage it himself.
key_stories.challenge: Repetitive-strain injury from weightlifting affects development comfort.
key_stories.process: Visited doctor, heard treatment plan, evaluated side effects vs needs.
key_stories.outcome: Opted for self-care; shares skepticism toward medical advice during stream.
key_stories.key_quote: He diagnosed me with a tennis elbow. He said he might have to inject steroids … I said nah.

open_questions.context: Kaze dislikes the current switch and failed initial redesigns; no replacement decided.
questions: What visual style and feedback cues are you aiming for with the new blue-coin switch?
Have you set any performance or poly limits for that object?
Who on the team will own the redesign (art vs. code)?

open_questions.context: Level needs an underground area with an 8-bit pipe, but Kaze admits he has no idea how it will work yet.
questions: What gameplay purpose will the underground serve beyond aesthetics?
Will new mechanics or enemies be introduced there?
How will it tie into star objectives and player routing?

open_questions.context: Kaze feels red-coin mission lacks variety; brainstormed oil spots but remains undecided.
questions: What interactive properties will oil surfaces have (slip, damage, buoyancy)?
Are there technical constraints to simulating oil behaviour on N64 hardware?
How will visual clarity be ensured so players recognise oil hazards?

open_questions.context: Kaze debates making a ‘fuck-you hard’ final stage but worries about frustrating casual players.
questions: What criteria define acceptable difficulty spikes in RTYI?
Could optional post-game content satisfy hardcore players without gating endings?
How will checkpointing be handled in late-game courses?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes that 20 FPS views cause rotation stutter in Course 1 and plans to fix algorithm.
questions: What causes the current interpolation bug, and what solutions are under investigation?
Is the target minimum frame rate on hardware 20, 25, or 30 FPS?
Will a performance-testing checklist be added for future assets?
